reviewText:
I'd never encoutered a rougelike before. Never knew what the term meant till Spelunky. And now I totally get the appeal.

Spelunky plays like a great side scrolling platformer. Maps randomly generate everytime you play through and the options to get to the end of each map are expansive. Having limited health and resources adds to the tension of the game and players have to balance the urge to speed run and resource management.

The controls are sharp. I played on both the keyboard and 360 controller and highly recommend the latter, but it's not required.

The graphics have a nice clean animation sytle to them and I love the fact I'm given the choice of whom to rescue (woman, man, dog). And while the alternate unlockable playable characters are nothing more than new skins, unlocking them all does take some effort.

My biggest complaint/recommdation: don't play this right after Super Meat Boy or any other speed runner. This is not that type of game. You will die. Alot. And it'll take a long time to beat the game if that's your mentality.

reviewText:
I bought this game for Co-op, and am reviewing it as a co-op game.

The gameplay itself is actually quite fun, but there are two major points I have to criticize:

- The camera in the co-op mode only follows one player. The other players will quickly lose orientation and find themselves outside of the screen. This made coop a lot harder and more frustrating than singleplayer.

- The game doesn't let you take your time and explore. This forces you to rush the game even more, making the bad camera even worse. Again, this counts for co-op. The time limit is managable in singleplayer.

Another thing is fairness: This game is hard. There's nothing wrong with that. But often even small mistakes are punished by instant death. An enemy might hit you once and before your character recovers hit you again, until it's game over. This can by very frustrating, but of course the challennge can also be a plus.

My reason for not recommending this is the local coop mode. If you're playing alone anyway you might as well give it a try.

reviewText:
Spelunky is a game where you the player must fight a army of evil shopkeepers and their evil pet monkeys that won't give you anything for free. With your trusty damsel weapon you can block arrows, smash monsters, set off traps, and sacrifice it once every level for a new item. You must find the book of the dead then like a ninja make your way to hell and kill the SOB that took your master. Spelunky is one of the best rogue-like games out there and it's very unforgivable if you make a mistake. It's more addicting then sex and crack as you ride a shark through a flaming hoop in space; with two times more asking if your doing it right, I can't feel anything, crying, and withdrawal.  There is also a two plays mode where you and your wife can fight over whos fault was it that you both die, which later ends in divorce. Becareful not to take too long on each stage or a transgender ghost of christmas past will come and make you explode.  I give this game a 9 out of 10 Shigeru Miyamotos.

The good+
+Kickazz soundtrack.
+sold game and nice controls.
+dying a lot and taking it like a man, unlike all those easy made games now of days for chickens.
+many items and weapons to shoot a Shopkeeper in the face with.
+fun for the whole family untill one of you go crazy from losing and kills your family off. Then the cops come after you and it ends in a blood festival with party hats, balloons and a shoot out where you go down like a thug showing the world you don't give a flying f--k.

The Bad-
Sometimes if you don't want to beat up a evil shopkeeper, a monster can hit them and set him off flying at your azz.

reviewText: I bought this game out of impulse because I really liked the original. Hoping it would be the same thing but with updated graphics and achievements, I got it right away, but soon  found out it was an updated  port  from the 360 version. Right away I didn't like the music (each level area has a randomized track set, hit and miss) and thought some of the character animations were really awkward. I was pretty quick to dissmiss the game and had a bad taste in my mouth from what in my opinion was an over priced arcade game, but I came back to it a few days later and got hooked. I was able to look past some of the flaws I didn't care for in the game and was able to enjoy it for what it is, a brutal, unforgving yet rewarding platformer.\n\nMy only complaint about the game is the unlockable characters, I love the idea of course, but just wish they had some context, seemed like a bunch of random characters with silly outfits, I like the robot, but thats just me.

reviewText:
Amazing platformer with rogue-like elements, the difficulty makes you wanna play the game over and over. Might be hard in the beginning, but the more you play the better you get. You might die in the first stages in your first hours of gameplay but eventually, after a lot of practicing and raging, you'll make your way to the final stage to finish of Olmec and completing the game.

However, if you are looking for a bigger challenge than Olmec (which I am sure of you will) you can make your way to another stage after Olmec by collecting certain items during your run. After that stage, you will take on Yama. Very difficult at first, but just like the entire game: practice enough and you'll get there, no matter how hard it seems.

Even after you finished of Yama, the game still has some stuff to offer.
The achievements are quite the challenge but really encourage you to keep playing the game.

Beat the game and all achievements? Speedrunning and playing secret levels or as different characters is fun as hell (inside joke) as well.

It's the challenge that keeps you going.


Bonus: there are a lot of streamers out there on Twitch who stream Spelunky regularly which is very fun to watch as well. I recommend BananasaurusRex (does a lot of WR attempts and speedruns) and BaerTaffy!

reviewText: Great game. It reminds me a lot of Castlevania. This game is worth every penny. Music is good, graphics/animations are awesome, sound effects are superb. So many things to do. Like unlocking new characters and such. The main part of this game is the difficulty; which is based on skill rather than luck (you can get lucky/unlucky, though). The control scheme is flat out easy, making this game extremely easy to become addicted to. There are so many items to collect/use, giving awesome perks, and making gameplay that much more enjoyable. Best played with a controller. There is no unfair advantage; forcing you to become better at overcoming the odds. Random generated levels so you won't get used to the same thing over and over. This game really dusts off the old NES skills. Good job, we need more games like this on steam.

reviewText: At first, the game seems impossible. Literally - it's tough to imagine even making it out of the first set of 4 levels on first pickup of the game. It's frustrating, and, initially, left me unimpressed with the game. But, sticking through the tough first few levels and forcing yourself to be more careful, more dilligent with your movements, and taking your time to think through the level (though not too long, lest the ghost show up!) really pays off. Spelunky seems relatively harmless and shallow at first glance, but I can honestly say that this is one of the most consistently rewarding and challenging games I've ever played. And that's not even to mention the sheer complexity of the game -- at surface level it may seem that each run will turn out similarly, but that is just not the case. Rough spots in levels will kill even the most veteran players with ease, and learning how to deal with increasingly complex death traps is a key point in the game that will take a lifetime to master given the inherent randomness of each new map.\n\nIt's an incredible game you can sink some time into. You have to be mentally present to play it and cannot just half-♥♥♥ your way to a victory. Buy it.

reviewText: Potentially my favorite game on Steam (at least in the top 3), Spelunky exudes polish from every angle.  The initial road is punishing and extreme, and there is some trial-and-error involved with learning the game's levels and traps, but once they are ingrained in your mind, you'll find yourself breezing through much of the game.  This is a game that rewards careful planning over running in blind.  The graphics/artstyle fit the theme perfectly, and I don't know if I've heard a better soundtrack to a game in my life.  An absolute must-play!

reviewText:
Spelunky is a devilishly addictive game.
At its core, it's a compelling platformer with really satisfying controls.
Procedurally-generated levels keep the challenge fresh, but they are still based around a fixed set of enemies and traps, allowing you to improve. (There's quite a few secrets to discover, too.)
That is key because Spelunky is pretty hard, but tight controls and experience give you a fair chance at fighting back -- and getting further and further down the levels feels rewarding.

I was already hooked to the XBLA version, and the Steam-exclusive daily challenge only made the addiction worse. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Spelunky is one of my favorite games of all time and I can't recommend it enough. It is one of few soul crushingly difficult games where your deaths come with very little frustration, and with every death you get a better understanding of the game, and the better your understanding of the game becomes, the less frustration there is to be had. And that is a huge feat given that the game is randomly generated and features perma-death. There is so much depth to the mechanics in place and so much you can do with them and the way in which they can work together to ♥♥♥♥ you over in glorious fashion is more often than not hilarious. You'll laugh at an absurd (but well deserved) death when one tiny mistake spirals off into a rube goldberg-like chain of ♥♥♥♥ery, even if you're on the brink of progressing past a point you've never reached before.

There's so many things to learn and it can be overwhelming at first, but it is so worth it. The accomplishments you'll make along the way, big or small, feel so incredibly satisfying, from just making it past the mines, to finding the black market, to killing Old Bitey, beating Olmec, unlocking the city of gold, getting to hell, successfully robbing a shop, ghost mining, speedrunning, and so much more. The skill ceiling is incredibly high, but you don't have to be a god at the game to enjoy yourself, and you're always getting better, a failed run is a new lesson learned in how to approach whatever it was that screwed you over the last time. Mastering Spelunky was one of the most rewarding experiences I've had with a game, and I can only hope to play something as good as it again.

Thanks to Derek Yu & Andy Hull for their amazing work.

reviewText:
Spelunky is a game where you the player must fight a army of evil shopkeepers and their evil pet monkeys that won't give you anything for free. With your trusty damsel weapon you can block arrows, smash monsters, set off traps, and sacrifice it once every level for a new item. You must find the book of the dead then like a ninja make your way to hell and kill the SOB that took your master. Spelunky is one of the best rogue-like games out there and it's very unforgivable if you make a mistake. It's more addicting then sex and crack as you ride a shark through a flaming hoop in space; with two times more asking if your doing it right, I can't feel anything, crying, and withdrawal.  There is also a two plays mode where you and your wife can fight over whos fault was it that you both die, which later ends in divorce. Becareful not to take too long on each stage or a transgender ghost of christmas past will come and make you explode.  I give this game a 9 out of 10 Shigeru Miyamotos.

The good+
+Kickazz soundtrack.
+sold game and nice controls.
+dying a lot and taking it like a man, unlike all those easy made games now of days for chickens.
+many items and weapons to shoot a Shopkeeper in the face with.
+fun for the whole family untill one of you go crazy from losing and kills your family off. Then the cops come after you and it ends in a blood festival with party hats, balloons and a shoot out where you go down like a thug showing the world you don't give a flying f--k.

The Bad-
Sometimes if you don't want to beat up a evil shopkeeper, a monster can hit them and set him off flying at your azz.

reviewText:
I can't stop playing Spelunky. I've beaten it several times, gotten through Hell, found just about every secret there is to find, and I keep coming back for more.
It's the perfect game. Challenging as hell, almost entirely skill-based (some luck comes in with item availability), different every time, and addictive. I play Spelunky while listening to podcasts, which it's perfect for. I've yet to find another game that works as well as a podcast companion.

For real, buy this game. It's totally worth the full asking price. If it's discounted, why aren't you playing it right now?

reviewText:
The best platformer I have played in ages, with a random level generator that knows the mechanics of the game so well it never puts you in front of an unfair situation where you cant get past without taking damage. It all comes down to pure player skill. That said, you will die a lot, and each time you die you will have to start from scratch in a new randomly generated series of maps. Because of that it never gets frustrating like other games where you might not be able to get past that one map, and you do the same ♥♥♥♥ over and over again.
The daily challenge is a fantastic addition too. It plays the same as every other set of levels, except the daily challenge is the same for everyone across the world, making it perfect for leaderboards. And you only get one chance: die and you have to wait till the next day for a new challenge. I fully recommend this game.

Also, there's more than just 'be touched by creature and die'. One time I threw a rock to explode a box of TNT... I hit my mark, the force of the explosion catapulted the rock back into my face. I got knocked off a ledge onto an altar to Kali and accidentally sacrificed myself. (people have to lie down on the altar for it to work so you can walk on it. But because I got knocked off my feet I lay for a second. and *POOF*) That made me lose my ♥♥♥♥ completely, I laughed so hard!

10/10, would accidentally sacrifice myself to Kali again.

reviewText:
Spelunky is one of my favorite games of all time and I can't recommend it enough. It is one of few soul crushingly difficult games where your deaths come with very little frustration, and with every death you get a better understanding of the game, and the better your understanding of the game becomes, the less frustration there is to be had. And that is a huge feat given that the game is randomly generated and features perma-death. There is so much depth to the mechanics in place and so much you can do with them and the way in which they can work together to ♥♥♥♥ you over in glorious fashion is more often than not hilarious. You'll laugh at an absurd (but well deserved) death when one tiny mistake spirals off into a rube goldberg-like chain of ♥♥♥♥ery, even if you're on the brink of progressing past a point you've never reached before.

There's so many things to learn and it can be overwhelming at first, but it is so worth it. The accomplishments you'll make along the way, big or small, feel so incredibly satisfying, from just making it past the mines, to finding the black market, to killing Old Bitey, beating Olmec, unlocking the city of gold, getting to hell, successfully robbing a shop, ghost mining, speedrunning, and so much more. The skill ceiling is incredibly high, but you don't have to be a god at the game to enjoy yourself, and you're always getting better, a failed run is a new lesson learned in how to approach whatever it was that screwed you over the last time. Mastering Spelunky was one of the most rewarding experiences I've had with a game, and I can only hope to play something as good as it again.

Thanks to Derek Yu & Andy Hull for their amazing work.

reviewText:
This remake of a modern classic is one of the prettiest 2D games I've played in a very long time. The cartoony, retro artstyle with iconic, clownishly bulbous noses won me over in a heartbeat when I played the original, and now that it's updated I can be smitten with it all over again.

Spelunky combines the finest platforming mechanics with the high risk and deeply strategic challenge of roguelikes of yore. Back when the original game came out in 2008, its success revived the roguelike genre. That's how good this thing is.  According to the Berlin Interpretation, this game is not really a roguelike, but just between you and me, the Berlin Interpetation is a steaming load.

Gittan gud at Spelunky isn't nearly about learning tactics and mastering controls (although those are both very important, too) so much as it is about becoming fluent in the system. As you play the game more and become more and more intimately acquainted with its rules, you get better and better at parsing the game state at a glance so you can hack together a plan at a moment's notice. Even if you're in no immediate danger, assessing the danger you

reviewText: There are few games that frustrate me as much as Spelunky can. There are also few games that I will return to so regularly. Once you overcome the steep learning curve this game it won't be easy by most standards, but you will have a lot less difficulty with it and you might even be able to beat the game multiple times. My main failings now are trying to complete more hell runs to get my high score even higher. The Daily Challenges will bring me back to play for at least twenty minutes each day.\n\nIn short I would recommend this game highly, especially if it's ever on sale. Easily worth the asking price.

reviewText: Probably the most beautiful and cute 2D roguelike PC game as of now. Excellent gameplay formula with incredible replayability from randomized levels. Nice atmospheric music. Tight and precise control. Dynamic haiku that greets you everytime you open the game. Satisfying unlockable shortcut system. Lots of character to unlock. A well polished game that lets you develop skill and reflex overtime.\n\nThis the roguelike game that makes sense the most. Things don't try to kill you for no reason or forcing to be a roguelike without clear reasoning. There is a back-story / concept that makes it all make sense, unlike many roguelikes out there that cheaply try to kill you without clear reasoning / concept of why.

reviewText: Spelunky combines the thrill of roguelike exploration and discovery with the skill-based challenges of a precision platformer. Each area feels unique not only in atmosphere but in the challenges it presents, and exploration is frequently rewarded with new characters or secret items. This game is not for everyone, but those that enjoy the frequent-death, rinse-and-repeat style of games like VVVVV and Super Meat Boy will find in Spelunky a refreshing, innovative twist on the genre.\n\nThe HD version features more than just updated graphics: new characters, new items, new areas, and a new boss await fans of the original free-to-play Spelunky. As a fan of the original, I can heartily recommend this port - it is definitely a significant expansion well worth the investment.

reviewText:
What a stellar remake of an already amazing game! I first picked up Spelunky Classic a year or two after it came out, and found myself thoroughly addicted for months. I was hesitant to pick up this version since I had already seen everything Classic had to offer, but Spelunky HD did not let me down. The new areas, enemies and items breathed new life into an old classic and the gameplay tweaks made it a much more polished experience.

Pros:
* Detailed new graphics brimming with personality.
* A jazzy, memorable new soundtrack. Miles better than the old one.
* Loads of new content. The game is about 50% bigger than the original.
* Achievements, which let veteran players push their skills to the limit.
* Dog kissing parlors.

Cons:
* The more organic physics take some getting used to.
* Missing some features Classic had, like some Kali rewards and a playable Tunnel Man.
* The new enemies and obstacles made an already-insane game even more difficult.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed Spelunky Classic. And if you haven't played Spelunky Classic yet, give it a shot before you try this game out to see if it's for you.

reviewText:
This is an incredibly difficult game, but so good at the same time. You will want to play it over and over and over again. Your deaths may often seem unfair, but that fuels the desire to play again even more. Anyway, the game itself is a randomly generated platformer with treasure and monsters to find and deal with. The art style is good and the music/sounds are all fine. The goal is to get from the beginning of each room to the end of each room while getting the most treasure and not dying.

Pros:
Good art
Very challenging
Infinite Replayability
Good music

Cons:
Controls are just a tad wonky. Not awful though

Overall I would give this game a 9/10. It is a great game if you want a challenge but don't have the time for some big title games. The price on it is good, but I'd suggest a sale. Also, I think the original GameMaker game is free on the internet, so try that out before buying this one to see if you would actually like it.

reviewText:
Fantastic 2D platformer that I will never quite get tired of, I still play it every now and then despite it being an old purchase.

I first heard about this game by watching a Let's Player play the xbox version, I was immediately convinced to try the original PC version (as the updated one wasn't out on PC yet) and loved it. If you wish to try the old PC version before purchasing this one, by all means: http://spelunkyworld.com/original.html

As for the updated version, a lot of good new features and items, still very difficult and still very fun. A real test of your reflexes and mechanical skill as it often pits you up against one-sided situations that must be bested before you can claim the title of having beaten this game. The difficulty is also very fair, so you get to blame yourself for every death.

The game has fifteen default levels (and a boss at the end) that must be beaten in succession, after learning the game in and out you'll be surprised to hear it's not over yet as there are another three levels (and a boss at the end!) after the final boss". There are also five hidden levels. Oh and you must beat all of this in succession
recommended: in one life.\n\nHas a score attack element to it too
hoursPlayed: when you eventually get good enough to consistently beat the game you can try to get the highest score
voteText: still plenty of fun and lots of challenge.\n\nIt doesn't matter how many times you die
helpfulPercent: you will want to try again and again and again to get further and further than you've ever been before! All levels are randomly generated
votesHelpful: so you will never be the same place twice."

votesFunny: true

reviewText:
Extemely challenging yet rewarding roguelite platformer. That said, it is not a twitch platformer like Super Meat Boy. Rather, the difficulty comes from the myraid enemies and traps, and caution, not reflexes, will be your greatest asset. If you are frustrated easily, this game may not be for you, but when I finally beat this game for the first time, it was the most satisfying feeling I've ever had in my life.

And then I immediately started another game and died on some spikes.
10/10 Would  die buy again
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you have had fantasies about being Indiana Jones, then this game just might make your dreams come true.

Spelunky is a merciless 2D platformer that will not hand anything to you. Aside from the short tutorial, which will introduce you to the basic controls, the game of Spelunky is yours to explore.

The game offers four main areas, with an additional bonus level. All of the areas are designed with unique challenges, and are always auto generated. Therefore, each time you play (or replay) an area, it will never resemble the previous one you just played.

The game is very difficult, as anything that can kill you, will kill you. However, the game is also rewarding to play, despite its sadistic tendencies to deprive you of your hopes and dreams. Therefore, trial and error are a significant aspect of the game and Spelunky will more than simply challenge your endurance and wits.

Even though caution is advised, you cannot spend too much time loitering around as there is a 2.30 minute limit before a ghost appears that will attempt to hunt you down and kill you, ending your pitiful life and throwing you back to ground zero.

A worthwhile indie game, 10/10.

reviewText: Extremely hard and awesome Indie platformer in which everything, stationary or mobile, is out there to kill you. Every dungeon is randomly generated and every death will only respawn you at the beginning lobby.\nThis game teaches you everything the hard way. What is that monkey gonna do?" reviewText:
My Game of the Year 2013 for PC.

Spelunky is best described as a roguelike platformer where your goal is to adventure deeper and deeper into the mines and survive while getting as much loot as possible. Every death is permanent and you will start at the beginning. And you will die. A lot. But that's okay, since the world is random generated so every playthrough is different.

This game was designed for the XBOX360-controller. It is still playable on a keyboard, but you should definitely invest in an XBOX360-controller if you don't already have one.

+The best controls I have ever seen in a game (provided you play with an XBOX360-controller!)
+Excellent and tight gameplay.
+Good soundtrack.
+Hours and hours of entertainment.
+Compete on the leaderboards.

-Can be frustrating at times. (No kidding.)

reviewText:
Spelunky has become one of my favorite games since I purchased it. It combines arcade platforming with devastating perma-death and randomized levels that work so well I have yet to experience a single death that I can blame on the game. Instead, there are a multitude of deaths I have to blame on myself. But after every death, the slight progress made in the next run is more than enough motivation to continue playing.

For someone that demands a story or graphics to carry them through a game, this is not a purchase to be made at full price. The graphics are simple and the story concise (albiet almost non-existant) to properly focus on the beautiful mechanics of the game. These mechanics create opportunity to continue playing the game after the first completion with different challenge runs or different paths. Instead of going through the normal levels you can travel into the stomach of a giant worm, go to a castle, or visit a black market filled with goodies for you to buy (or steal!).

In my opinion, to get the most fun out of Spelunky I recommend a controller. A keyboard will do the job, but it doesn't feel nearly as fluid to me.

reviewText: People criticizing this game seem to have expected something else. This is not a single, go through the it once kind of game. You will die a lot. The point is to get better and have fun while you do it. I still haven't gotten past the jungle but you don't hear me complaining because I know that it's going to take a long time to get good enough to complete. This isn't a game for everyone, but if you enjoy classic titles where it takes patience and dedication to beat, this game provides greatly. Also, the random level generation gives plenty of replay value. I would definitely not recommend playing without a game-pad of some sort, personally. It will make it harder than it's supposed to be. I would however suggest that you try to the original free version of Spelunky before you play this one to get a feel of how this game works, but the graphics in this are much better and the game-play overall feels better to me.

reviewText:
Spelunky is the best game. You know games? This one is better than all of them. It has great precision platforming, replayability forever, and difficulty that tests both knowledge and skill. You are going to die. It's going to happen often. You won't know that enemy was capable of attacking you that way. And then you'll immediately started again with important new knowledge. You can't get by the difficult platforming sections based purely on muscle memory because the layouts constantly change, you instead need to learn the game. How far you can jump from a standstill or running, how that changes with items, how far you can fall without damage, the range and time delay on your whip; you need to get the mechanics down to succeed. You'll probably start out rushing into everything and dying thirty seconds into the game, then you'll take it ridiculously slow and be terrified of everything, then you'll play at a speed somewhere between the two and amaze anybody still living in phase 2.

There's an endless amount of challenge, not only from the randomized layouts but also from hidden levels, secret items to find, and achievement-encouraged alternate ways of playing the game. There's an Achievement for finishing the game with $500,000 worth of treasure. There's also one for finishing the game with $0 worth of treasure, which is so very much harder to do than the high score. Speed runs are encouraged and also the sort of thing crazy people do.

Spelunky is good. Really, really good. If you've ever liked a platformer, try Spelunky.

And the soundtrack. That god damned soundtrack. Just buy the game so you can hear the most triumphant WE'RE GOIN' ON AN ADVENTURE" title music of all time."

reviewText: This is pretty much roguelike-platformer: prepare to die edition. If you don't know what's spelunky all about: it's a game about Spelunky Guy (yea) who descends into deepest depths of mines and looks for some ULTIMATE TREZUREEEEE (to the max). Games involves some basic controls (dpad, A,B,X,Y and 1 trigger should be enough), also some oldschool mechanics, like the items you actively use must be carried (so no throwing rocks if you're holding a laser gun). I find it a little bit annoying but I guess that's how the game was supposed to be. Even though you can prevent death by being extra careful this game is really hard at times (particularly when you're racing against time). If you love roguelikes and dying a lot before you progress and perfect your game, this game will serve you right.

reviewText:
Spelunky is one of my favourite games. The constituent parts are simple - it's a platformer with strong rogue-like elements. That is, permadeath with random levels, and as hard as nails.

A good complete playthrough will take about 20 minutes, but you'll spend tens of hours perfecting your skills to get to the stage where you can actually beat the game.

The controls are perfect, the mechanics extremely well tuned, and the game never feels unfair. Every situation is navigable, every death preventable, it just depends upon your skills. And deaths are hilarious - they're usually something really stupid you've done.

I once saw a streamer (Anthony Burch of HAWP fame) daze himself from falling and ended up accidentally sacrificing himself on an altar, killing himself instantly. Right near the end of the game.

My favourite part of this game is just how much the randomness affects the game strategy and gameplay in general. Random levels often feel bland and uninspired, but Spelunky manages to make the randomness really matter. You have to make meaningful decisions and hedge your bets. I could use a bomb, but, I've only got 3 left and might need to use a couple later on..

Anyway, this is the cream of the crop as far as platformer roguelikes go. There are none better, that I've played.

reviewText:
A very good adventure game that makes you think ahead about plotting your path to the end of the level instead of barreling ahead blindly spamming bombs.

Death is a learning experience in this game and will help you understand the attack ranges of each and every enemy from the Cobra to the huge spider, even those pesky shopkeepers, should you choose to pick up a literal steal.

The Daily Challenge mode is there to break the montony of Adventure mode.  Try picking up every single peice of gold and every gem for the high score!

reviewText: A procedurally-generated platformer programmed with the sole purpose to kill you. You die after the shopkeeper shoots you because a frog exploded in his shop on the other side of the level after it got hit by a trap, and now he blames you. You die because you whpped a spider too close to an explosive crate, and some of the spiders blood hit the crate, setting it off. You die because you touched a yeti, and even though you built up 20+ health, he threw you against a wall where you bounce right back into his arms, trapping you in an endless loop of furry death. You die because the NPC you hired to help you has an obession with whipping every pot in the level, and hits you by mistake, sending you off a ledge and into a spike pit. You die because you fell too far, landed on an altar, accidentally sacrificing yourself to a Hindu goddess. I don't know if I'd say you get better" at this game over time

reviewText: An extremely challenging dungeon crawl, Spelunky provides players with an equal level of satisfaction and frustration with every playthrough. It's a dungeon crawl that i find particularly enjoyable because while many recent dungeon crawls and roguelikes (or pseudo-roguelikes) have some sort of progression with each playthrough (i.e. unlockable weapons, items, or characters with unique abilities), the only benefit from playing through Spelunky is an increase in understanding of the levels and experience to help you conquer the ever changing levels. Spelunky is among the most challenging and satisfying games I have ever played, and it keeps me wanting more. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Okay, first this is a great game and you should play it.

But which version?

If you have friends who like to visit your physical house, then you should buy this version or the XBox version so that you can make use of the local multiplayer. No doubt the shenanigans can only make this game even more awesome.

But if you don't have local friends, I'd suggest checking out the dev's website. There he distributes for free an earlier version of Spelunky which is fairly much the same game. Most of the mechanics are the same between versions and the largest differences are the change in artstyle and the addition of several new types of enemy and a (few?) level(s).

That said the transition between the new and old versions isn't completely plain sailing. There are slight quibbles with both that keep them on par. For example, the shopkeepers in the old version pause when they leave the screen making them supremely exploitable, whereas in the new version they do not. Likewise in the new version arrow traps fire horizontally, which makes them far less fun and far more gotcha than the arcing arrow traps that the older version uses which will not catch you off guard if you accidentally run at them from off-screen.

So overall, if have friends, buy this great platformer, grab some controllers and have fun. If don't have friends, play the game for free until you wisk to pay the dev some money for being awesome (and increase the difficulty marginally).

Just in case you're not convinced this is a great game, it's a very strong platformer, with the focus on going fast and jumping accurately so you can traverse the level and collect all the gold before it launches a heat-seeking kill ghost after you. And even that you can out platform.

The rest of the game relies on many interlocking subsystems that work brilliantly together, and it's a matter of learning what you can pull off when that determines how well you do beyond the simple jump puzzle. For example, you can jump on most enemies to defeat them. But a couple will punish you for jumping on them. But as soon as you pick up some spike boots, at least one of the enemies no longer retaliates due to the spiky death. So there's this constant game of I have these items so these strategies are open to me" that keeps discovery fresh
date: and makes this game very replayable.\n\nSo 5/5. Just don't expect to win very frequently if you anger all the shopkeepers consistently (like I do)."

reviewText: Spelunky, what can I say about this game that hasn't already been said. It's a roguelike game that sends you through 4 different main areas, each containing 4 stages. There is also a secret second end game with another 4 levels, as well as more secret levels with just one stage. The game has a large variety of items, and a larger variety of out comes, you'll have a run were there's money everywhere, you're finding jetpacks and bombs left and right, and you'll have playthroughs were you fall into spikes on 1-1, the game just keeps giving you surprises. And the acheavements, oh the achevements. They keep you playing until you have them all. There is so much more I could rant on about on this game, but just keep in mind, you will die, and you will die a lot. For any help, ask the people over at http://www.reddit.com/r/rspelunky for help, and enjoy your Spelunking!

reviewText:
If you have had fantasies about being Indiana Jones, then this game just might make your dreams come true.

Spelunky is a merciless 2D platformer that will not hand anything to you. Aside from the short tutorial, which will introduce you to the basic controls, the game of Spelunky is yours to explore.

The game offers four main areas, with an additional bonus level. All of the areas are designed with unique challenges, and are always auto generated. Therefore, each time you play (or replay) an area, it will never resemble the previous one you just played.

The game is very difficult, as anything that can kill you, will kill you. However, the game is also rewarding to play, despite its sadistic tendencies to deprive you of your hopes and dreams. Therefore, trial and error are a significant aspect of the game and Spelunky will more than simply challenge your endurance and wits.

Even though caution is advised, you cannot spend too much time loitering around as there is a 2.30 minute limit before a ghost appears that will attempt to hunt you down and kill you, ending your pitiful life and throwing you back to ground zero.

A worthwhile indie game, 10/10.

This game's fun. It's a 2d platformer where you journey deep to get mad cash, to get there, though, you'll go through randomly generated levels with initially cruel difficulty. First off it's fun as to play because the controls are spot on. people have said super meat boy was spot on but it was loose as hell but this game has perfect controls. some nerds might say it seems clunky at the start but after just a bit of playtime it works perfectly. Of course the shortcuts which take you to later levels don't count for scores, and can't be used in things like the daily challenge, but it's great that they put it in as you a. might want to not play a full game and b. might want to see all the content earlier.

Buy it it's fun asf.

reviewText: Probably the best video game I have played in years. If you enjoy roguelike games you owe it to yourself to buy this game.

reviewText:
Spelunky is a hard sell.

Dark Souls is a hard sell, but I can say with authority that the game rewards you for being patient and skillful.  Spelunky is... you know how carnival amusements and claw machines are literally programmed to make sure you don't win?  Like f'rinstance, the claw only closes one in every 1,000 plays?  Spelunky feels a lot like that.  You play, hoping the levels give you what you need to win - knowing that, FAR more often than not, you are going to die in a few minutes/seconds.

You know the game is going to pull cheap moves on you - like giving you the jet pack, the shotgun, all the tools you need to find the secrets of the game... and then springing a dark level full of giant spiders and spikes.  This game is brimming with one-hit kills.  This game is overflowing with cheap deaths.  This game is absolutely teeming with a litany of gurgling curses, choked-out between spittle-spraying clenched teeth uttered by the players over the last few years; getting rocked by the spikes after a monkey jumped on their back, bounced(unconscious) into a caveman who threw them 40 feet in some kind of Rube Goldbergian, assisted-suicide Kevorkian machine tends to breed a depth of crude language that we spent eons evolving *out* of - I have learned swear words I did not know were in my own vocabulary.  The whip is too slow, you can hurt yourself by tossing a rock 2 feet into the air and having it crush your skull, and arrow traps haunt my nightmares.

So why do I play?

VENGEANCE.  I play this game out of the pure engine of hatred that it has built within me, solely to crush the dungeons and see those smarmy shopkeepers blasted by their own shotguns.

10/10, would hate self again.

reviewText:
Got given this as a gift by a friend and can't stop playing it.  It's got huge replayability, and although it's infurianting to master, it's rewards and polished gameplay are well worth the time to invest.

The single player mode and online daily challenge keeps it fresh also, although the deathmatch isn't great.

Recommended to anyone who wants a game they can pick up and play around a busy lifestyle!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game’s title should be  “trial and error” .  You’ll die a lot in this game and to continue any further, you’ll have to learn about your mistakes.

You have to be very patient and careful  while playing Spelunky, rushing through the levels will get you killed immediately.  Any mistake will punish you here.   So I wouldn’t recommend this game to impatient people or people that don’t like the  “trial and error”  mechanic.
The game’s hard but not frustrating   (In my opinion, dying in this game makes you want to play more) , there’s  a lot of content and variety  (items, enemies, levels, etc), the visuals are unique and even if the game’s 2D, it really dives you into it.
I love the concept of the  Journal:  it’s a book with all the information of the game (places, enemies, items…) that you fill up once you interacted with it for the first time. For instance, you forgot what an item does you can check what it does. But I think I like the drawings, yeah… I like the drawings more.

My complaints would be that   it takes some time to get used to the controls.
Even though it’s about learning from your mistakes, sometimes obstacles are almost impossible to avoid leading to  cheap deaths   (trust me, there’s a lot of BS).
It’s a shame  there’s a lot of characters but they’re just skins,  it would have been cool if they started with different starting items/ abilities.

Still a very addicting game where you rescue  pugs.  Yup,  pugs & drawings  are my jam.

reviewText:
Spelunky is an extremely difficult indie Roguelike platformer. It’s Roguelike in that all of the levels, terrain and enemies in the game are randomly generated, which helps keep the game fresh and interesting. It reminded me quite a bit of Rogue Legacy with its excellent design and brutal difficulty.

The object of each level in Spelunky is to get to the exit, but you’ll have to navigate through lots of traps and other enemies in a randomly generated level. Your character will start with a limited supply of bombs and ropes to help you navigate the level. Bombs can be used to destroy terrain and dig deeper while ropes can be used to help you climb back up. You don’t always want to just race to the exit when you find it either, you’ll want to explore the level and gather as much gold and upgrades as you can find before leaving. But if you spend too long in any given level, a giant ghost that can kill you instantly appears to chase you out of the level. There’s also a maiden hidden in each level. If you bring her to the exit, she will restore one point of your health, so you’ll want to try to find and rescue her in each level. You’ll find shops hidden in each level where you can spend your gold to replenish your bombs/ropes, and buy weapons and upgrades. Spelunky also features local co-op which is pretty fun, but still just as hard.

It’s a very difficult game, but if you don’t get frustrated it’s a very addictive game as well. I’ve actually yet to make it past the third level in this game, but I’ve gotten close a few times. Check it out if you enjoy difficult platformers

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

reviewText: 10/10\n\nA must buy for any hardcore platformer fan. This is a hugely challenging and entertaining game that will have you hooked for days – if not weeks. reviewText: This game is amazing. I see a lot of people complaining about the ghost after the 2 minutes and 30 second mark in each level. reviewText:
Spelunky is a cave-exploration, treasure-gathering roguelike platformer, where you take the role of an Indiana Jones-type explorer.  Levels are dynamically generated each time you play, and when you die, you must start from the beginning of the game.  The goal is essentially to make it to the end of the game (or at least, as far as you can go!) without dying and while gathering as much treasure as possible.  The game also reminded me a lot of Dark Souls, one of my favourite games, in that is hard.  You will die often, probably in the first level, and there is little room for error.

This is a lot more fun that it might sound.   Spelunky is a deceptively simple, challenging, and deep action-adventure platformer and one of the best games I’ve ever played.

Basically, you enter a new level, and must make your way to the exit at bottom of the mineshaft or ancient temple.  Along the way, you can gather treasure, rescue “damsels” by carrying them with you to the exit, or even plunder sacred idols and avoid massive boulder traps.  Levels become progressively more difficult – you must avoid snakes, spiders, skeletons, deadly traps, spikes, and bottomless pits, to name only a few, all while trying to collect treasure and helpful items.  Tools at your disposal include your trusty whip, ropes, bombs and a multitude of other interesting powerups and weapons.  If you’re lucky you can even find a jetpack!

The controls are incredibly precise and responsive.  You can jump, walk, sprint, pick up items and throw items, or even use items that you can carry with you.  The game would be incredibly frustrating if you were ever fighting the controls, as the game leaves no room for error.  But, it gives the player perfect control and you will never blame the controls for an untimely death.  If you’ve ever played Super Meat Boy, you’ll have an idea of what makes these controls so great: they’re fast, responsive, precise, and intuitive.  Additionally, the game has superb hitboxes, and you’ll never feel like you got killed unfairly by something that shouldn’t have hit you.

Each level in Spelunky is procedurally generated and is different every time you play.  The levels themselves are completely destructible – you can use bombs to blast a path directly to the exit, or else use a pickaxe to mine some rare gems.   There are also a number of different environments, including an underground jungle and an alien-filled ice cave, which keep things fresh and keep you motivated to push forward.  The game is therefore never about memorization – you can’t memorize the jumps or traps or enemy patterns.  The focus is always on mastering the gameplay, and mastering the intricate interlocking gameplay systems.

As mentioned, death in Spelunky comes fast and frequently.  You start a game with four hearts, which you can replenish by rescuing damsels.  However, any number of things can kill you instantly or take a big chunk of your health – falling on spikes, or getting caught by an arrow trap, or even blasting a wall and getting caught by the resulting debris.  Spelunky is all about learning from each run and each death, and applying that to your next run – whether you learn that you can throw a bomb into cobwebs to blast the giant spider lying in wait, or you learn not to carelessly throw rocks which can land back on your head.  Frequent death never bogs the game down – you can quickly jump right back into the game when you die, without any lengthy loading screens.

Spelunky for Steam has detailed, clean graphics reminiscent of a Super Nintendo game.  The environments, characters and enemies are full of personality and are well animated.  The cutesy appearance, however, belies some of the brutal deaths your character will experience, whether that means getting shredded by a shotgun, or impaled by spikes, or incinerated by a bomb.  This mismatch between the surface appearance and the harsh difficulty and violent deaths lends the game a lot of humour.  Likewise, the audio is varied and well-done, and fits the visuals perfectly.

One of my favourite things about Splunky is the number of hidden secrets.  There are hidden levels, secret items, and so many interesting ways to use even the most mundane tools.  The game even includes a completely hidden final dungeon and a “true” final boss, which most players will probably never experience or even discover!

Overall, I would highly recommend Spelunky to fans of platformers, and anyone who enjoys challenging, well-designed games.  There is so much replayability, and so much room to master its deep and rewarding gameplay.  Spelunky is a joy to experience, and one of the best games I’ve ever played.

reviewText: Collect treasure. Outsmart, outrun or fight through creatures and traps. You will get hosed by a yeti that throws you across a cave onto spikes. You will lose hold of your weapon and drop it into lava. You will be assaulted be a suprisingly agile shopkeeper over misunderstood intentions. You will die often, losing everything, having to start over from the beggining. Somehow all of those things will make you laugh more often than cry. You'll never see the same cave twice so it's endlessly replayable. Many difficult acheivements and daily challenge leaderboard give incentive to keep coming back for more even after you've managed to beat it a few times. Between the original version and the Steam version I'd guess that I've made it through maybe 20 times in about 2500 attempts.

reviewText:
Spelunky is a rogue-likish 2D platformer, where the player takes the role of a treasure hunter in seek of riches within an ever-shifting labyrinth. The gameplay is fluid, the visuals are appreciable, and the music has a mysterious, enticing vibe.

Although difficult and often frustrating, Spelunky is a great joy to experience, and will always have you clicking that retry button. The game offers a local Co-Op option, where up to 4 players can work together (or hilariously kill one another). If the main gameplay is becoming stale, there are mini-games available, such as one with the sole goal of killing other competitors.

Everyday, players can compete against others in daily challenges. The Daily Challenge is a game mode where all players explore the same generated map, with the goal of achieving the highest possible score.

It's worth mentioning that, although the PC controls aren't terrible, the game is best played with an Xbox controller. Demanding hours upon hours of gameplay, Spelunky is an absolute must buy for rogue-likish enthusiasts, as well as players looking for an enjoyable experience, all for a reasonable price of $15 at full price.

reviewText: After polishing the original free Spelunky game and reproducing an HD version, Spelunky HD takes all the juicy goodness from the original game and elevates everything, even the gameplay difficulty. The random number generated levels throughout the endeavour provides varying experiences of gameplay, and when the player dies, it is often a result of the player's clumsiness and own fault. The large number of smaller activities within the whole game, including the infamous Eggplant challenge, Daily Challenge, fighting arena and also the ultimate task of beating Hell and getting high scores, allows Spelunky HD to be a game that has countless replayability, despite the drastically increased difficulty, resulting in large amounts of deaths. 9/10

reviewText: One of my favorites, great for a quick jump into something fun, and can suck you in for a long time. It's challenging in the way good roguelikes are, and much more accessible. This problem doesn't exist in the recently released PS Vita version, but per Derek Yu (the creator) it may or may not be fixed on the PC one, I expect it won't. All the same, give this one a shot, it'll be a gaming staple for you from here on out.

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game enough. It's brilliant.

It's one of those games that gets its hooks in you and you just can't stop. The Daily Challenge provides a fun little experience where every player gets the same seed and you go for the highest score.
The game is difficult though. I won't lie. Dying on a Daily by a stupid mistake or a jump that didn't go to plan does make you want to scratch out your eyes. If you like to go for achievements and stuff, good luck. Collecting no treasure on a run or completing the game in under 8 minutes will test you like never before. There are even a bunch of cool mods that have been made for this game.

All in all, I love everything about Spelunky. Don't think about it, just buy it.
And if you buy this, go into the settings and change the damsels to Pugs. It's the only way.

reviewText:
Spelunky is one of those games you can't stop playing. It hooks you with its shear difficulty and urges you to keep going. Despite every death you take you will still play as every time you die you will realise that it wasn't the game's fault. It was yours.

And thats what makes Spelunky so good. Every time you die you blame yourself and try to do even better. Add in the secret areas and the ultimate goal of reaching Hell and beating the true final boss Yama (not got to him quite yet despite clocking over 6 hours of play so far and having played the original). Spelunky is definetly one for any hardcore gamer.

Just watch for those dart traps. And be prepared to die. A LOT!

reviewText: I often lament the lack of games of Spelunky's calibre. I think game developers would do well to look to it as an example of an already good game that has been polished well. I've played a lot of the original freeware version, mods like Tastes Like Spelunky and now the remake. My friend gifted me this on steam as the GOG version doesn't have daily challenges and given how much I go on about Spelunky he thought I was missing out.\n\nI would wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone. The extra content added is great and the changes and fixes are welcomed. No longer will I accidently kill damsels with sticky bombs! I'd also very much recommend going into this game blind as reading up about anything will greatly diminish the enjoyment of seeing new things and finding things out. If you've played the remake and not played the original you should amend that.

reviewText:
Spelunky has become one of my favorite games since I purchased it. It combines arcade platforming with devastating perma-death and randomized levels that work so well I have yet to experience a single death that I can blame on the game. Instead, there are a multitude of deaths I have to blame on myself. But after every death, the slight progress made in the next run is more than enough motivation to continue playing.

For someone that demands a story or graphics to carry them through a game, this is not a purchase to be made at full price. The graphics are simple and the story concise (albiet almost non-existant) to properly focus on the beautiful mechanics of the game. These mechanics create opportunity to continue playing the game after the first completion with different challenge runs or different paths. Instead of going through the normal levels you can travel into the stomach of a giant worm, go to a castle, or visit a black market filled with goodies for you to buy (or steal!).

In my opinion, to get the most fun out of Spelunky I recommend a controller. A keyboard will do the job, but it doesn't feel nearly as fluid to me.

reviewText:
At first I didn't particularly like this game.  I thought it was far too difficult.  But, it was 2D, which meant it was one of the few games I own that I could enjoy with my wife.  We take turns playing the single player game and after a short while, we were both addicted.  It's now a thing we always do together.  We watch a little TV while we eat dinner, then we play Spelunky.  It's just someting that's part of our daily routine.

I absolutely adore this game now, both for the challenge it presents and for the time I get to spend with my favorite person.

As far as gameplay goes, it's frustratingly difficult and you will rage quit often.  However, the controls are tight and ultra precise and very rarely do you feel you lost because the game cheated you.  You can almost always find where you made a mistake and that was what resulted in your untimely death.

For difficulty, it took us around 100 hours to beat the first, normal boss.  For the secret, hidden, true boss it took near 170 hours!  That's a huge amount of bang for your buck!

I highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a great 2D platformer that doesn't pull any punches.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has made me cry on multiple occasions.
Don't get me wrong; this is a fantastic game and I have had a lot of fun playing it, but, just to give you an idea of how hard it is (for me, anyway) - I've played this game nearly 2000 times and have only won 2 times. Pretty crappy.
However, it is so satisfying when you do win - a feeling which I don't get from many games, which I think makes Spelunky special.
If you're up for a challenge, this is the game for you. But be warned - it may have adverse effects on your sanity.

reviewText: Highly addictive little adventure-platformer. With randomly generated levels, hundreds of different mobs, items and weapons, you can never get bored, even after you were *this* close to beating the game, but you were taken out at the last second by a pesky bat. Or a poisonous snake. Or falling onto spikes. Or many other gruesome, but cartoony ways of death. There are many ways to die in Spelunky, and that's one of the reasons why it's so addictive. You constantly discover new things about the game that you didn't know before. With only around 8 hours of my time taken up so far, I'm sure that Spelunky will take up hundreds upon thousands of hours of my life.

reviewText: It took me about 240 runs before i beat the end boss named Olmec for the first time (On the ps vita version though). And I still haven't seen all the levels. This game is strange in that it seems so very straightforward but hides a lot of branching paths and critical decision making. You'll find yourself deep into a run and realize that if you had made some other choice back a few minutes ago, you'd have been better off. It's a game of risk vs reward, with a brilliant ecosystem of enemies, traps and physics. And the daily challenge... just brilliant. Great community game if you're into that. Get it, play it, and realize, like so many others, that Spelunky is probably the purest form of fun and joy you'll find in video gaming.

reviewText:
Spelunky is an extremely difficult indie Roguelike platformer. It’s Roguelike in that all of the levels, terrain and enemies in the game are randomly generated, which helps keep the game fresh and interesting. It reminded me quite a bit of Rogue Legacy with its excellent design and brutal difficulty.

The object of each level in Spelunky is to get to the exit, but you’ll have to navigate through lots of traps and other enemies in a randomly generated level. Your character will start with a limited supply of bombs and ropes to help you navigate the level. Bombs can be used to destroy terrain and dig deeper while ropes can be used to help you climb back up. You don’t always want to just race to the exit when you find it either, you’ll want to explore the level and gather as much gold and upgrades as you can find before leaving. But if you spend too long in any given level, a giant ghost that can kill you instantly appears to chase you out of the level. There’s also a maiden hidden in each level. If you bring her to the exit, she will restore one point of your health, so you’ll want to try to find and rescue her in each level. You’ll find shops hidden in each level where you can spend your gold to replenish your bombs/ropes, and buy weapons and upgrades. Spelunky also features local co-op which is pretty fun, but still just as hard.

It’s a very difficult game, but if you don’t get frustrated it’s a very addictive game as well. I’ve actually yet to make it past the third level in this game, but I’ve gotten close a few times. Check it out if you enjoy difficult platformers

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:

reviewText:
The game’s title should be  “trial and error” .  You’ll die a lot in this game and to continue any further, you’ll have to learn about your mistakes.

You have to be very patient and careful  while playing Spelunky, rushing through the levels will get you killed immediately.  Any mistake will punish you here.   So I wouldn’t recommend this game to impatient people or people that don’t like the  “trial and error”  mechanic.
The game’s hard but not frustrating   (In my opinion, dying in this game makes you want to play more) , there’s  a lot of content and variety  (items, enemies, levels, etc), the visuals are unique and even if the game’s 2D, it really dives you into it.
I love the concept of the  Journal:  it’s a book with all the information of the game (places, enemies, items…) that you fill up once you interacted with it for the first time. For instance, you forgot what an item does you can check what it does. But I think I like the drawings, yeah… I like the drawings more.

My complaints would be that   it takes some time to get used to the controls.
Even though it’s about learning from your mistakes, sometimes obstacles are almost impossible to avoid leading to  cheap deaths   (trust me, there’s a lot of BS).
It’s a shame  there’s a lot of characters but they’re just skins,  it would have been cool if they started with different starting items/ abilities.

Still a very addicting game where you rescue  pugs.  Yup,  pugs & drawings  are my jam.

reviewText: A brilliant game, great value for money as the game is endless too. Spelunky is an aquired taste however, it is by no means easy, and the frustration involved in dying tops that of which I experience playing the binding of isaac. I think the best thing about Spelunky is its quirky charm, a neat little indie game with lots of imperfections, but these imperfections make the game interesting and unique, the best quality in all indie games. The enemies are fairly standard and the music is good but not astounding, but I think the aesthtics make it really stand out from other games. The design of the levels have been thought out carefully (side note: if you wish to learn the unique way the game was made, watch indie game the movie's special edition features) and I think how the surroundings change as you progress keeps what you're seeing interesting. 9/10, great game but it could have a better soundtack in my opinion. If you're unsure whether you would find the game unenjoyable get it on sale.

reviewText:
Spelunky has become one of my favorite games since I purchased it. It combines arcade platforming with devastating perma-death and randomized levels that work so well I have yet to experience a single death that I can blame on the game. Instead, there are a multitude of deaths I have to blame on myself. But after every death, the slight progress made in the next run is more than enough motivation to continue playing.

For someone that demands a story or graphics to carry them through a game, this is not a purchase to be made at full price. The graphics are simple and the story concise (albiet almost non-existant) to properly focus on the beautiful mechanics of the game. These mechanics create opportunity to continue playing the game after the first completion with different challenge runs or different paths. Instead of going through the normal levels you can travel into the stomach of a giant worm, go to a castle, or visit a black market filled with goodies for you to buy (or steal!).

In my opinion, to get the most fun out of Spelunky I recommend a controller. A keyboard will do the job, but it doesn't feel nearly as fluid to me.

reviewText:
Okay, first this is a great game and you should play it.

But which version?

If you have friends who like to visit your physical house, then you should buy this version or the XBox version so that you can make use of the local multiplayer. No doubt the shenanigans can only make this game even more awesome.

But if you don't have local friends, I'd suggest checking out the dev's website. There he distributes for free an earlier version of Spelunky which is fairly much the same game. Most of the mechanics are the same between versions and the largest differences are the change in artstyle and the addition of several new types of enemy and a (few?) level(s).

That said the transition between the new and old versions isn't completely plain sailing. There are slight quibbles with both that keep them on par. For example, the shopkeepers in the old version pause when they leave the screen making them supremely exploitable, whereas in the new version they do not. Likewise in the new version arrow traps fire horizontally, which makes them far less fun and far more gotcha than the arcing arrow traps that the older version uses which will not catch you off guard if you accidentally run at them from off-screen.

So overall, if have friends, buy this great platformer, grab some controllers and have fun. If don't have friends, play the game for free until you wisk to pay the dev some money for being awesome (and increase the difficulty marginally).

Just in case you're not convinced this is a great game, it's a very strong platformer, with the focus on going fast and jumping accurately so you can traverse the level and collect all the gold before it launches a heat-seeking kill ghost after you. And even that you can out platform.

The rest of the game relies on many interlocking subsystems that work brilliantly together, and it's a matter of learning what you can pull off when that determines how well you do beyond the simple jump puzzle. For example, you can jump on most enemies to defeat them. But a couple will punish you for jumping on them. But as soon as you pick up some spike boots, at least one of the enemies no longer retaliates due to the spiky death. So there's this constant game of I have these items so these strategies are open to me" that keeps discovery fresh
date: and makes this game very replayable.\n\nSo 5/5. Just don't expect to win very frequently if you anger all the shopkeepers consistently (like I do)."
hoursPlayed: true

reviewText:
Spelunky is an extremely difficult indie Roguelike platformer. It’s Roguelike in that all of the levels, terrain and enemies in the game are randomly generated, which helps keep the game fresh and interesting. It reminded me quite a bit of Rogue Legacy with its excellent design and brutal difficulty.

The object of each level in Spelunky is to get to the exit, but you’ll have to navigate through lots of traps and other enemies in a randomly generated level. Your character will start with a limited supply of bombs and ropes to help you navigate the level. Bombs can be used to destroy terrain and dig deeper while ropes can be used to help you climb back up. You don’t always want to just race to the exit when you find it either, you’ll want to explore the level and gather as much gold and upgrades as you can find before leaving. But if you spend too long in any given level, a giant ghost that can kill you instantly appears to chase you out of the level. There’s also a maiden hidden in each level. If you bring her to the exit, she will restore one point of your health, so you’ll want to try to find and rescue her in each level. You’ll find shops hidden in each level where you can spend your gold to replenish your bombs/ropes, and buy weapons and upgrades. Spelunky also features local co-op which is pretty fun, but still just as hard.

It’s a very difficult game, but if you don’t get frustrated it’s a very addictive game as well. I’ve actually yet to make it past the third level in this game, but I’ve gotten close a few times. Check it out if you enjoy difficult platformers

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

reviewText: A procedurally-generated platformer programmed with the sole purpose to kill you. You die after the shopkeeper shoots you because a frog exploded in his shop on the other side of the level after it got hit by a trap, and now he blames you. You die because you whpped a spider too close to an explosive crate, and some of the spiders blood hit the crate, setting it off. You die because you touched a yeti, and even though you built up 20+ health, he threw you against a wall where you bounce right back into his arms, trapping you in an endless loop of furry death. You die because the NPC you hired to help you has an obession with whipping every pot in the level, and hits you by mistake, sending you off a ledge and into a spike pit. You die because you fell too far, landed on an altar, accidentally sacrificing yourself to a Hindu goddess. I don't know if I'd say you get better" at this game over time
date: you mostly just learn how to deal with things after they kill you ten times."

reviewText: An extremely challenging dungeon crawl, Spelunky provides players with an equal level of satisfaction and frustration with every playthrough. It's a dungeon crawl that i find particularly enjoyable because while many recent dungeon crawls and roguelikes (or pseudo-roguelikes) have some sort of progression with each playthrough (i.e. unlockable weapons, items, or characters with unique abilities), the only benefit from playing through Spelunky is an increase in understanding of the levels and experience to help you conquer the ever changing levels. Spelunky is among the most challenging and satisfying games I have ever played, and it keeps me wanting more. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Spelunky is a hard sell.

Dark Souls is a hard sell, but I can say with authority that the game rewards you for being patient and skillful.  Spelunky is... you know how carnival amusements and claw machines are literally programmed to make sure you don't win?  Like f'rinstance, the claw only closes one in every 1,000 plays?  Spelunky feels a lot like that.  You play, hoping the levels give you what you need to win - knowing that, FAR more often than not, you are going to die in a few minutes/seconds.

You know the game is going to pull cheap moves on you - like giving you the jet pack, the shotgun, all the tools you need to find the secrets of the game... and then springing a dark level full of giant spiders and spikes.  This game is brimming with one-hit kills.  This game is overflowing with cheap deaths.  This game is absolutely teeming with a litany of gurgling curses, choked-out between spittle-spraying clenched teeth uttered by the players over the last few years; getting rocked by the spikes after a monkey jumped on their back, bounced(unconscious) into a caveman who threw them 40 feet in some kind of Rube Goldbergian, assisted-suicide Kevorkian machine tends to breed a depth of crude language that we spent eons evolving *out* of - I have learned swear words I did not know were in my own vocabulary.  The whip is too slow, you can hurt yourself by tossing a rock 2 feet into the air and having it crush your skull, and arrow traps haunt my nightmares.

So why do I play?

VENGEANCE.  I play this game out of the pure engine of hatred that it has built within me, solely to crush the dungeons and see those smarmy shopkeepers blasted by their own shotguns.

10/10, would hate self again.

Spelunky is among the most challenging and satisfying games I have ever played, and it keeps me wanting more. Highly recommended.

reviewText: Story: You are a spelunky (spelunker?) and you have discovered Olmec's caves, a place where death has lost it's way and your soul will literally not be put to rest if you die (so you just come back to life basically), in Olmec's little home lies treasure. You want that treasure. However, there are many foes! Bats! Spiders! Giant Spiders! Snakes! Tiki People! Frogs! And much more. Sounds simple, yes? WRONG. Olmec will be sure to break you. Want to prove him wrong? Then play this game if you dare.\n\nAlright onto the real review. The game is absolutely fantastic. You could play the game the normal way" and honestly miss A LOT of extra things you probably didn't even know about. You carry a whip
recommended: and some ropes. You can acquire more from boxes
hoursPlayed: purchasing (or stealing if you're feelin' lucky) some from shop keepers or finding some underground (sometimes). reviewText: Spelunky is one of the best games I have ever played. It solves very well many of the troubles that are present in traditional platformers, while conserving the fast pace of gameplay and adding more interesting decisions. Because of its random generation, the game will never force you or even give you the option to replay levels that you have already played, meaning that it is a new and fresh experience each time, and it actually tests your ability to platform rather than how well you have memorized its levels. The controls are very tight, and the random generation is one of the most fair that I have ever seen; rarely will you get a level that is significantly more or less difficult than average. Also notable is that the average run length is very very low, maybe 1-5 minutes for a new player, since you will be dying a lot. A successful run (don't expect this at first) will take close to 20.\n\nThe game does have its flaws: personally I find the game significantly more difficult when playing with keyboard controls, and because the character jumps very low to the ground but runs very fast it plays significantly different from most platformers (you'll get used to this, don't worry). By far the biggest flaw is its difficulty curve. The first several runs where you make it to a new area will basically be oh
date: that kills you?" and you unexpectedly and hilariously die. At the end of the difficulty curve comes the endgame of score running and speed running and challenge running and things... I did these things because there were acheivements for them (like 200 hours into the game btw)
recommended: and while I definitely enjoyed getting those acheivements
hoursPlayed: if you're actually trying to top (any of the) leaderboards or do some of the most difficult challenge runs (eggplant run) the game basically comes down to reseting for a good seed and taking every risk. But that's all strictly optional
voteText: and at least for me the option came after a few hundred hours of enjoyment.\n\nThough I've thought a lot about the game's flaws
helpfulPercent: I love it. I spend a lot of time replaying the game and keeping my skills sharp
votesHelpful: even if I'm focussing on some other game at the time. I strongly recommend this game."

reviewText: “Spelunky is the best game ever made. I’ve been dancing around saying that for the last seven years of writing about its different forms, but I feel confident about it now. It’s funny when you die from a rock flung by a bounce pad, or because a friend climbed over a ledge and accidentally dropped a knife on your head. It’s exciting when you discover a jetpack buried in the rock at an easily accessible spot. It makes you feel clever when you wield your few remaining resources towards reaching the City of Gold. It is brilliantly designed and I know game designers who credit it with inspiring their careers. And it’s £2.74. The best game ever made for £2.74.” 10/10 would mattock again!

reviewText: I have bought this game twice: on Xbox and PC. I have beat the game, beat the City of Gold, and I have been to hell twice. I have yelled swear words at my own stupidity. I thank and blame all the people who introduced me to this game. Although I joke about how unfair and bull**** the game can be, it is one of the most well thought out and balanced games you will ever play. It is arguably my favourite games, where it an leave you in tears, or celebrating because you did an 'amazing' trick of whip an arrow out of the air. This game makes you, as another review put it, a 'Spelunky Machine' where you play out the game in your head, evaluating risk, reward and ability of a task before you do it. Obviously, anyone who's played the game will vouch for how OP the blue frogs are, and how the crush blocks will **** you into nothing when you were that close to reaching hell. In short, buy the freakin' game and complain about it for yourself.

reviewText:
Easy to play, hard to master.
This game is hard, but fair. Everytime you die, you know you made a mistake. It's never rng. You can calculate everything and can be pretty good in this game, if you can be patient.
It took me ~80 hours to get all the achievements in this game. And still after that, I come back to it and play the daily challenge or just a normal run by time, cause this game is fun.
Don't give up, when you die. Learn from your mistakes and be better next time!
It's worth the money.
