reviewText: Spelunky is one of the best games I have ever played. It solves very well many of the troubles that are present in traditional platformers, while conserving the fast pace of gameplay and adding more interesting decisions. Because of its random generation, the game will never force you or even give you the option to replay levels that you have already played, meaning that it is a new and fresh experience each time, and it actually tests your ability to platform rather than how well you have memorized its levels. The controls are very tight, and the random generation is one of the most fair that I have ever seen; rarely will you get a level that is significantly more or less difficult than average. Also notable is that the average run length is very very low, maybe 1-5 minutes for a new player, since you will be dying a lot. A successful run (don't expect this at first) will take close to 20.\n\nThe game does have its flaws: personally I find the game significantly more difficult when playing with keyboard controls, and because the character jumps very low to the ground but runs very fast it plays significantly different from most platformers (you'll get used to this, don't worry). By far the biggest flaw is its difficulty curve. The first several runs where you make it to a new area will basically be oh
date: that kills you?" and you unexpectedly and hilariously die. At the end of the difficulty curve comes the endgame of score running and speed running and challenge running and things... I did these things because there were acheivements for them (like 200 hours into the game btw)
recommended: and while I definitely enjoyed getting those acheivements
hoursPlayed: if you're actually trying to top (any of the) leaderboards or do some of the most difficult challenge runs (eggplant run) the game basically comes down to reseting for a good seed and taking every risk. But that's all strictly optional
voteText: and at least for me the option came after a few hundred hours of enjoyment.\n\nThough I've thought a lot about the game's flaws
helpfulPercent: I love it. I spend a lot of time replaying the game and keeping my skills sharp
votesHelpful: even if I'm focussing on some other game at the time. I strongly recommend this game."

reviewText:
Do you like hard retro games?
No, I mean harder than Mario and Sonic and all that.
No, I mean harder than the fairly challenging neo-retro games like Cave Story and Shovel Knight.
No, I mean harder than the REALLY hard retro games like the Castlevania and Ninja Gaiden series.
No, I mean harder than tough-as-nails neo-retro stuff like La-Mulana and probably even Super Meat Boy.
Yeah, you heard that right.  I'd say this game is harder than Super Meat Boy.  Maybe even I Wanna Be the Guy.
But.. in a different way.  A more thoughtful way.  I daresay a better way.
But do you like them?  Then this game's probably for you!

Seriously though, unlike those other games I mentioned that either aren't that hard to begin with or bank on extreme difficulty just for the sake of it and usually though unforgivingly pixel-perfect platforming and extreme precision-memorization, the likes of which didn't even exist to nearly to such a degree in the 8-bit-era games they claim to be trying to emulate, Spelunky is simply difficult in that it has an extremely high skill ceiling... and I would say a pretty high skill 'floor'.  You can play the tutorial and mess around in the game as a complete gaming amateur that only understands the very basics of platforming and smacking things with a whip, but to really get anywhere or do anything, there's a LOT you're going to need to get used to, learn, experience and master.  I'd definitely compare it most closely out of what I listed to the 'Castlevania/Ninja Gaiden' and Cave Story/La-Mulana groups, inspired by classic games that required lots of play and development and refinement of skill rather than split-second platforming perfection or mind-numbing memorization.. which is to say, a superior type of 'extreme difficulty' than the likes of Super Meat Boy and its ilk (as much as I do enjoy that game).  I'd also compare it to a sort of 2d Dark Souls/Monster Hunter in a similar way, except replace very difficult bosses to master" with "very difficult traps and stage setups to master".

Except.. unlike all of those

reviewText:
I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:
http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2013/04/spelunky.html
(Note: This review was based on the freeware game, which this game is an enhanced version of.)

What sets this game apart?
Spelunky is a very simple game.  You play as an Indiana-Jones-esque explorer with a bullwhip and fedora, progressing through 16 stages in four blocks while collecting treasure, fighting monsters, and saving damsels in distress.  What makes Spelunky different than other platformers is that it could be classified as a rogue-like game.  For those who aren’t familiar with the term, rogue-like games feature randomly generated levels and permanent death.  Each of the four blocks provides some variables to the stage layout, but each is otherwise random.  When you die, you start over from the beginning.  This makes it both a challenging and addictive platformer with infinite potential.

What is the difficulty factor?
This game is a great example of “easy to learn, difficult to master.”  There is a short tutorial level available, but not required.  As with most platformers, the core of the controls is run, jump, and attack.  You get access to other tools, starting with bombs that remove tiles in an area and ropes that allow you to climb up or down to new areas.  Eventually you may come across weapons, mining implements, relics, and other gear such as parachutes and compasses.  While the basic mechanics of the game are very straight forward, the multitude of tools can take some experimentation.

From a challenge perspective, I have to start by saying that while the concept is simple, this game is intentionally hard.  Killing enemies and making your way to the exit using minimal items doesn’t seem like it should be hard, but every strike and every jump has to be perfect.  Chances are you will die a lot.  The good news is, unlike most rogue-likes, this game has a sort of check point system.  When you reach the end of each block for the second time, you will be given the chance to pay an NPC to dig a shortcut for you.  The amount you have to donate will likely take you several trips, but the result is the option to start at stage 5, 9, or 13 instead of back at 1 every time.  This takes what would be a nearly impossible task for most players and gives them smaller goals along the way, making the game much less frustrating and more fun.

Does it use media effectively?
While Spelunky sports a great retro look with sprite graphics and chiptune music, they are by no means its selling point.  Everything in the game is recognizable and well designed, and each of the four blocks has its own tile set, music, and troupe of enemies and traps.  The game looks much better on a smaller screen or in windowed mode, however.  An enhanced version of the game was released in 2012 on the X-Box Live Arcade, which keeps same designs and gameplay, while greatly enhancing the graphics.

Best moment in the game?
As this is a game driven much more by mechanics and goals than story, I feel like the best moment in the game is likely reaching a goal rather than a specific point in the game.  The obvious goals like beating the last boss, unlocking a check point, or even simply not dying are great, but I have to say that the best moment is successfully reaching the hidden area: The Lost City of Gold.  This is not an easy task to accomplish, and while just reaching it is a goal, the heaps of treasure you can obtain within will likely give you a high score you will never match.

Who needs to play this game?
This game is a great pick up and play option for anyone who is a fan of classic games that has anywhere from 10 minutes to 10 hours to kill.  This is not a game for the easily frustrated, as there are a lot of ways that your hard work can be undone with a split second mistake (my total win/death count is around 3/1000).  Short term goals like check points make this more tolerable, and eventually the goal changes from beating a block to achieving a high score.  The enhanced version is available for X-Box Live Arcade, Playstation Network, and Steam. The classic version is available for download here: http://spelunkyworld.com/original.html

reviewText: This is my favorite platformer of all time. I do not speak lightly of such things! I spent untold hours with the .99a version, dying a thousand times over before winning once, and the final polished game is THAT MUCH HARDER. I don't know if I'll ever win, but I'll have fun trying.\n\nBest, and most addictive, use of careful randomness in game design that I have seen so far. Fast paced and brutal, but never impossible.

reviewText:
If you enjoy oldschool platforming with super tight controls that let you know YOU made the mistake, not a shoddy game mechanic, then prepare to tear your hair out with the brilliant masochism that is called Spelunky.

The three things to know as you start playing:

1. Dying starts you over at the beginning. You lose everything.
2. The levels are randomly generated. Sometimes they are a breeze, but more often than you'd expect to be ok with, you're thrown into a Rube Goldberg machine of death.
3. You will die. A lot.

This is an amazing and addicting game. Definitely purchase if you enjoy platformers. If it's on sale, i recommend anyone to pick it up. It's a blast (har har).
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Spelunky is magnificent. Amazing. Superb. Sublime. It's platforming heaven, mixed with rogue-like randomization, Overwhelming deaths. Endless retries. Careful exploration. Careless slips. Daring escapes. Rash risk-taking.

It's a wonderful experience - a heady mix of clever and fun gameplay, with the challenge of the unknown and brutally difficult experiences. It's a feeling that few other games instill in me. I've died, but it was my fault so gosh darn it, I'm going to try that again. And again. And again!

Full of humour and life, I really recommend this game. I played a few thousand times on the original, and I'm rapidly clocking up the hours in this one. Just one more attempt.

reviewText:
What makes Spelunky different from your average game?
The average game coaxes you gently. It gives you a gentle push in the right direction, like a father teaching a son how to ride a bike. It watches eagerly as you improve and master the game.
Spelunky pushes you onto the ground and beats you again and again with a club until you agree to its terms. Then, it watches as you try to survive and fail yet again. And it laughs.
But when you conquer the average game, you feel like you've done no more than a walk down a straight path.
When you conquer Spelunky, you feel like you've climbed the mountain.
COME PLANT YOUR FLAG UP HERE WITH THE REST OF US!

reviewText:
Spelunky, what more can be said?

It's like Mario combined with Indiana Jones complete with Yetis, jungle men, cavemen, UFOS, angry shopkeepers (if you annoy them), AND Egyptian stuff too as far as I've gone.

There's also a damsel in distress, three choices, a lady, man, or pug, go with the pug, just do it!!

Not to mention traps, load of them! Oh, and by the way, its made even better with an xbox controller and multiplayer!

Beware! Be warned! If you've stuck around too long, and that means very long, a ghost comes to haunt you, don't take the skull idol either!!

Its SO ADDICTIVE! AS MUCH AS MINECRAFT!

reviewText:
After spending a decent amount of time playing Spelunky on the 360 and PC, I have come to love this game for many reasons.
The levels are randomly generated which adds a massive amount of replayability to the game, the leaderboards are highly competitive and forever changing with the addition of a Daily Challenge, which is the same map for every person on 1 day.
The game has much hidden content too if you choose not to research anything on the matter!

All in all, I highly recommend this game if you have a vague interests in rogue-lite platforming games.
